entry.et: Middle English (Scots), from Latin votum vow, wish vow

def.dt: :a usually formal expression of opinion or will in response to a proposed decision
:one given as an indication of approval or disapproval of a proposal, motion, or candidate for office
:the total number of such expressions of opinion made known at a single time (as at an election)
:an expression of opinion or preference that resembles a vote
:ballot 1
:the collective opinion or verdict of a body of persons expressed by voting
:the right to cast a vote
:the right of suffrage :franchise
:the act or process of voting brought the question to a vote
:a method of voting
:a formal expression of a wish, will, or choice voted by a meeting
:voter
:a group of voters with some common and identifying characteristics the labor vote
:a proposition to be voted on
:a legislative money item
:appropriation
:to express one's views in response to a poll
:to exercise a political franchise
:to express an opinion consumers…vote with their dollars Lucia Mouat
:to choose, endorse, decide the disposition of, defeat, or authorize by vote he was voted out of office
:to adjudge by general agreement :declare
:to offer as a suggestion :propose I vote we all go home
:to cause to vote in a given way
:to cause to be cast for or against a proposal
:to vote in accordance with or in the interest of vote your conscience voted their pocketbooks
:to express one's disapproval or dissatisfaction by leaving
:a deciding vote cast by a presiding officer to break a tie
:an unofficial vote taken (as at a chance gathering) to indicate the relative strength of opposing candidates or issues called also straw poll
:a parliamentary vote taken by calling for ayes and noes and estimating which response is stronger
:a vote cast by writing in the name of a candidate
:a candidate whose name is written in
